Award.AwardTitle: The geometry of nutritional niche separation among forest monkeys

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Studying present-day primate communities can help us to understand how they were shaped and maintained through evolutionary time. Adequate nutrition is critical for survival and reproduction. The goal of this research is to understand how monkeys meet their nutritional needs while sharing the same rainforest habitat. Dr. Jessica Rothman and her team will study the diet and nutrition of four monkey species and map the nutrients in trees in Kibale National Park, Uganda. The research will test hypotheses that will help understand their divergent nutritional goals. For example the researchers will test the hypothesis that different species of monkeys balance their intake of carbohydrates, fats, protein, minerals and toxins in different ways, which allows them to survive together in the same habitat. The research will be applied to scenarios of primate evolution and management strategies that affect primate conservation. Several graduate students and undergraduate minority students in STEM will participate in this research. They will observe wild primates, learn ecological field methods, and be trained in near infrared spectroscopy, nutritional modeling and plant analysis. This training will provide them with a unique international experience in a rainforest that hosts some of the highest densities of primates in the world. They will work alongside Dr. Rothman, a nutritional modeler from the University of Sydney, and conservation managers in the Uganda Wildlife Authority. The research team will also lead hands-on workshops on ecology and conservation at a Bronx middle school where students would otherwise have little opportunity to engage with nature.

This research takes a new approach to understand mechanisms that promote functional niche separation in primate communities, and examines species-level differences in traits at the nutritional level. Using the geometric framework of nutrition, novel hypotheses will be tested that are related to the divergence of nutritional goals of sympatric monkeys in Kibale, an African rainforest with a rich history of research that hosts a high density of primates. Through this research, the nutritional ecology of sympatric primate species will be comprehensively examined, and their patterns of nutrient balancing will be revealed. The researchers will conduct feeding observations of individual monkeys, assess food availability by analyzing the nutrients in every tree in each primate's home range via near infrared reflectance spectroscopy, and use the geometric framework of nutrition to test hypotheses about primate feeding ecology and nutritional goals. Through this research the research team will formulate general principles about the nutritional strategies among and within primate guilds and provide new insights into primate ecology by shedding light on the significance of nutritional ecology in niche separation, a previously understudied and under-recognized dimension of primate community ecology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Studying present day primate communities can help us understand how they were shaped and maintained through evolutionary time. Adequate nutrition is critical for survival and reproduction. The objective of this research was to understand how four different species of monkeys meet their nutritional needs while sharing the same rainforest habitat. The PI and her team studied the diet and nutrition of individual rainforest monkeys and mapped nutrients in trees in a tropical rainforest in Uganda. The research demonstrated that different species of monkeys consume different balances of protein and energy, and this provides a way for them to survive in the same habitat. Daily macronutrient and mineral intake profiles for each monkey species were established through different seasons and environments, providing the most comprehensive nutritional study on these monkeys to date. Leaf eating monkeys regulated energy in their diets, while frugivorous primates regulated protein, and each species consumed a different species-specific daily ratio of nonprotein energy to available protein.

This research took a new approach to understand mechanisms that promote functional niche separation in primate communities, and examined species-level differences in traits at the nutritional level.  Using the geometric framework of nutrition, novel hypotheses were tested that are related to the divergence of nutritional goals. This research formulated general principles about the nutritional strategies among and within primate guilds and provided new insights into primate ecology by shedding light on the significance of nutritional ecology in niche separation, a previously unstudied and unrecognized dimension of primate community ecology.

The broader impacts from this research were numerous. This research facilitated the training of PhD students at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York (CUNY). It also supported the training and retention of minority undergraduate students at Hunter College, a Minority Serving Institution in New York City. Students observed wild primates, learned ecological field methods, and they were trained in near infrared spectroscopy, nutritional modeling and plant analysis. In addition, through an agreement with the Uganda Wildlife Authority, CUNY PhD students and Hunter undergraduates were able to liaise with Ugandan park wardens in the field and conduct synergistic projects, providing a unique opportunity for international exchange. Six minority undergraduates participated in summer primatology research in Uganda, and many additional undergraduates participated in laboratory research. Of the six minority students, five are currently enrolled or have applied to graduate school in biological anthropology or environmental science. The PI and Hunter students also shared knowledge of primates with Bronx middle school students. This research was also applied in a conservation context in Uganda through understanding of the nutritional needs of primates.
